<font size="3">

For more info, see here:  
[https://scikit-learn.org/stable/datasets/toy_dataset.html#diabetes-dataset](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/datasets/toy_dataset.html#diabetes-dataset){target="_blank"}

The **diabetes dataset** is loaded using `load_diabetes()` function:

```{python}
from sklearn import datasets

# Load the dataset
diabetes = datasets.load_diabetes()
```

This returns a 'Bunch' object. Usually, it's more user-friendly to use the `as_frame` parameter which causes the 'data' and 'target' values to be loaded as data frames inside the Bunch object:

```{python}
# Load the dataset
diabetes = datasets.load_diabetes(as_frame=True)

print(type(diabetes['data']))
```

Either way, the Bunch object has the following keys:

```{python}
# Show the dataset's keys
print(list(diabetes))
```

More info on each of the keys:

| Key | Description |
|-----|-------------------------------------------------------------|
| `DESCR` | Description of the dataset |
| `data_filename` | Location of the CSV file containing the data being imported |
| `target_filename` | Location of the CSV file containing the target data being imported |
| `feature_names` | Names of the 10 groups of data |
| `data` | The 442 data points in each of the 10 groups of data, formatted as a 442x10 array |
| `target` | The target data, namely a quantitative measure of disease progression one year after baseline |

```{python}
# Description of the dataset
print(diabetes['DESCR'])
```

```{python}
# Location of the CSV file containing the data being imported
print(diabetes['data_filename'])
```

```{python}
# Location of the CSV file containing the target data being imported
print(diabetes['target_filename'])
```

```{python}
# Names of the 10 groups of data
print(diabetes['feature_names'])
```

```{python}
# The 442 data points in each of the 10 groups of data, formatted as a 442x10 array
print(diabetes['data'])
```

```{python}
# The target data, namely a quantitative measure of disease progression one
# year after baseline
print(diabetes['target'][:20])
```

The groups of feature data can be plotted against the target data as follows:

```{python}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Don't plot the sex data
features = diabetes['feature_names']
features.remove('sex')

# Plot
fig, axs = plt.subplots(3, 3)
fig.suptitle('Diabetes Dataset')
for i in range(3):
    for j in range(3):
        n = j + i * 3
        feature = features[n]
        axs[i, j].scatter(diabetes['data'][feature], diabetes['target'], s=1)
        axs[i, j].set_xlabel(feature)
        axs[i, j].set_ylabel('target')
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```
